item.title: Public toilets in Strasbourg
item.description:
Ever wondered around a city desperately looking for a public toilet? Fear not, the open data movement is here to help. The city of Strasbourg recently opened a new open data portal and while checking their available data sets I came across the one about public toilets. I guess every city should leak information about their public toilets.

I accessed the data by using an API and made a little map showing where to find the toilets.

Here is the final result:

PS: Public toilets in France are free.

item.title: Scraping a Wikipedia Table
item.description:
I tried the rvest package by scraping a Wikipedia table about communities in the Département “Bas-Rhin” in the region of Alsace in France. First thing to do is to load the necessary packages: rvest for scraping the website, tidyverse to clean the scraped data.

Scraping a webpage is surprisingly easy with the convenient rvest package. You only need little knowledge about CSS selectors to access the information you are interested in, in this case the whole table which is converted into a data frame.

The resulting data frame consists of 514 observations and 10 variables.

A first glance reveals that there are some problems with the data, which is typical for freshly scraped data. The following section deals with all the data preprocessing, for each variable one by one.

The clean data set can be downloaded here.

item.title: Demographics in Alsace
item.description: A little Shiny app that visualizes data from INSEE (the national statistics bureau of France) on communities in Alsace. This app was implemented in order to play around with Shiny and test its functionalities. Note that there is some missing data for a few units due to boundary changes.
